subject: Re: [junit] How do I implement a test case for a thrown exception ?
msgSnippet: IMO, the second and third catch don t buy you a thing. I guess you have them to show explicitly that they could possibly be thrown by the method under test.
messageBody:
IMO, the second and third catch don't buy you a thing. I guess you have
them to show explicitly that they could possibly be thrown by the method
under test. However, sticking to that pattern results in lots of changes
when adding or deleting an exception type from the throws block of a
method. Why not just add a "throws Exception" to the test method's
signature? The set of possibly thrown exceptions is in the
method-under-test's signature anyway.

Johannes

> If you want to eliminate the boolean, use your first example and do the

> public void test_00_isPartnerAssigned() {

> try {

> fail("IllegalArgumentException should be thrown.");

> } catch (IllegalArgumentException iae) {
>
> assert(true);
>
> } catch (PartnerNotFoundException pnfe){
>
> fail("PartnerNotFoundException should not be thrown.");
>
> } catch (PersistenceException pe){
>
> fail("PersistenceException should not be thrown.");

> }
